channel.title: Idea
channel.description:
I was talking to frank_ and I was thinking, what if the community wrote a deobfuscator together? Ok, that's a little far-fetched. More like, why don't select few accepted people from the community who can program well help to help create a deobfuscator that can tackle JAGeX's various annoying obfuscation, like arithmetic complicating, shift complicating, dummy arguments, dummy variables, method counters. Things we CAN'T reverse are things like name obfuscation or 'class spreading', where classes are split up into several static methods, like what happened to the World/SceneGraph class. The main reason is because deobfuscators aren't particularly hard to make, they are just very boring because you have to implement all these different transformers. Hopefully having multiple people will speed up the process and make it less of a bore. Anyway, who thinks this is a good idea?
Edit: Forgot to mention, also because writing an AST parser is going to be tough :P

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:22, topic:246307”][code]public final class ShiftFixer implements MethodTransformer {
private static AbstractInsnNode makePush(int val) {
if (val <= 5 && val >= 0) {
return new InsnNode(Opcodes.ICONST_0 + val);
} else {
return new IntInsnNode(Opcodes.BIPUSH, val);
}
}

public MethodNode transform(String owner, MethodNode mn) {
    ListIterator<AbstractInsnNode> i = mn.instructions.iterator(mn.instructions.size());
    while (i.hasPrevious()) {
        AbstractInsnNode insn = i.previous();
        int op = insn.getOpcode();
        if (op >= Opcodes.ISHL && op <= Opcodes.LUSHR) {
            AbstractInsnNode prev = insn.getPrevious();
            if (prev.getType() == AbstractInsnNode.LDC_INSN) {
                i.set(makePush(((Integer) ((LdcInsnNode) prev).cst) & ((op & 1) == 0 ? 31 : 63)));
            }
        }
    }
    return mn;
}

}[/code]

could be

public final class ShiftFixer extends ASTVisitorAdapter {
    public void visitShiftExpr(ShiftExpr ex) {
        if (ex.left().expr_type() == Expr.CONSTANT) {
            int i = ((ConstExpr) ex.left()).value();
            ex.set_left(new Constant(i & (ex.type() == Type.LONG ? 63 : 31)));
        }
    }
}[/code][/quote]
is now
[code]public final class IrrationalShift extends TreeAdapter {
    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
    public <T extends Node> T transform(T obj) {
        return (T) obj.accept(this, VisitOrder.PREORDER);
    }

    private static Expression rationaliseArg(BinaryShiftExpression shift) {
        Expression ex = shift.right();
        if (ex.sort() == INT_EXPR) {
            int value = (Integer) ex.value();
            int mask = (shift.type() == Type.LONG_TYPE) ? 63 : 31;
            return new IntegerExpression(value & mask);
        }
        return null;
    }

    public Expression visitShiftLeftExpression(ShiftLeftExpression expr) {
        Expression ex = rationaliseArg(expr);
        return ex == null ? null : new ShiftLeftExpression(expr.left(), ex);
    }

    public Expression visitShiftRightExpression(ShiftRightExpression expr) {
        Expression ex = rationaliseArg(expr);
        return ex == null ? null : new ShiftRightExpression(expr.left(), ex);
    }

    public Expression visitShiftUnsignedRightExpression(ShiftUnsignedRightExpression expr) {
        Expression ex = rationaliseArg(expr);
        return ex == null ? null : new ShiftUnsignedRightExpression(expr.left(), ex);
    }
}

i believe i have finished writing the first iteration of the AST, now for the parser and emitter :rolleyes:

ps: mitb fix code highlighting…

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:8, topic:292790”]Loops? I haven’t seen them.

I don’t think many people would be willing to release their deober open source. Thats the whole key to botting: the bot is open but the updater / deober is not.[/quote]

As frank_ said, a very well written updater doesn’t have to be afraid of being out in the open.

But we aren’t talking about an updater here, just a deobfuscator, which would in the end make updating much easier.

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Unhandled:

So if you deob at bytecode level then you should be able to decompile with no problems right? (assuming the deobber doesn’t suck)

That’s the problem, since current decompilers aren’t perfect it won’t give decent results. Unless you are going to remove those exceptions throws jagex added in almost every method, that way jad/jode will decompile decently.

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

frank_:

deob != decompiled client

Yea, deob stands for deobfuscated but deob is mainly used in the context of an deobfuscated and decompiled client.
Deobfuscation is not as hard as making an recompilable decompiled deobfuscated client.

Also you likely want to test your deobfuscation transforms and if you end up with errors it can be very frustrating if you don’t understand what went wrong (cause everything went ok).

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

The largest problem I had while writing my deobfuscater is that all current java decompilers give different errors on different places.

Look at the following decompiled ‘ad’ class (deobfuscated not renamed)
Jad: http://pastebay.com/35647
Jode: http://pastebay.com/35648
jd-gui: http://pastebay.com/35646

In this case only jd-gui gave a good result, but it fails on some other classes.

Eventually I just only used it for my updater and not for deobs (since a reflection explorer is just as useful, and looking through deobs doesn’t require it to be compilable)

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:8, topic:292790”]Loops? I haven’t seen them.

I don’t think many people would be willing to release their deober open source. Thats the whole key to botting: the bot is open but the updater / deober is not.[/quote]the general idea behind keeping the updater private is because you use weak rules and make assumptions that will be broken if made public, my current revision of my updater will always work unless jagex drastically change their data structures

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You forgot those horribly annoying loops they put in there that only execute once. I think it would be a great idea to have a nice framework that anyone could write plugins for, perhaps even with the option of using BCEL or ASM. I too think it would be best if it was available to the public, since it would assist budding bot developers in starting and would make them more willing to share their work.

I don’t see any reason why I couldn’t pay the developers out of the sponsored server fund either, as a well de-obfuscated client would make it much easier on server developers as well. I expect the fund to pass the $3000 mark after bidding ends this month (August 10th).

Do you think it has a better chance of succeeding if there is a monetary reward at the end of the rainbow?

Read full topic

item.title: Idea
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I think it’s a cool idea. I so no reason to keep it from the public after it has been developed though Cowie.
It’s not like we’re talking about software that they can run and all of their troubles will be over; it’s merely a tool to speed bot development attempts up (all of the newcomers will be able to have a good look around at client code, and it’ll be much easier than how it is currently).

Read full topic
